raw_response: {"answer_index": 3, "answer_text": "All of these", "confidence": 10, "reasoning": "Naloxone is a non-selective opioid antagonist that acts at all three major opioid receptor types: mu (μ), delta (δ), and kappa (κ). While it has highest affinity for mu receptors, it competitively antagonizes all opioid receptors. The student's answer of only kappa receptors is incomplete - naloxone blocks all opioid receptors, not just one type. This is well-established pharmacology.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
